content: I suggest you use Thunderbird filters rather than conventional copy or drag and drop.
creator: wsmwk

content: Thanks Wayne, please could explain how to do this? I would like to move all the emails from each year into a folder named after that year, so for instance, I have created a local folder called "2020" and I only want the inbox messages from that year to be copied to that local folder, and then copied from that local folder into the new IMAP folder with the same name for the new email address.
creator: dawson.thirteen

content:
TRy this: Would recommend you do a 'Copy to' because it will not delete anything off the original imap folder, so if a problem occurs at least you can redo it.

  • Tools > Message Filters
  • Click on New'
  • Give suitable name eg: Move by Date
  • Select 'Manually Run'
  • Uncheck 'Getting new mail'
  • Select 'Match all of the following'
  • 'Date' and 'is before' and insert date such as 01/01/2021
  • Click on the far right + icon to create another line
  • 'Date' and 'is after' and insert date such as 31/12/2019

Perform these actions:

  • 'Copy message to' - click on drop down hover over 'Local Folders' and select '2020'
  • click on 'OK'

The Filter called 'Date Move' is now in the list.

At the bottom of Message Filters:

  • On far right is 'Filter Log' button - click on it
  • Top right select checkbox: 'Enable the Filter Log'
  • then click on 'Close'
  1. 'Run selected filter on:' Choose 'Inbox on mail account name'
  2. Now - in list - select the 'Date Move' filter so it has a tick in checkbox as enabled and it is highlighted.
  3. Click on 'Run Now'

You may need to wait a while until it has completed and I suggest you do not select and view emails in Inbox whilst this occurs. Then you can check the Local Folders > 2020 folder I suggest you do check that you can read emails. So ensuring you do have full copy and not just headers. You can also the 'Filter Log' to see what was copied.

Once this has been done, you can use the same filter - just modify the year as required. But remember to create the necessary folders in Local Folders first.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
After you are completely sure you have full copies of all emails in the 'Local Folders' account, then you can delete emails from the old gmail account. Remember to compact folders after performing a deletion as this will completely clean up files in Thunderbird profile.

When coping everything back onto the new gmail email address...I would consider whether that is a real necessity. It will use up a load of your gmail quota. But useful if you need to see years of emails in another IMAP account on another computer or phone that accesses server. You will find that using imap to upload emails back onto a server has limits on how much is allowed, so you may find it takes a while. Upload with Imap has a 500mb per day https://support.google.com/a/answer/1071518?hl=en

All emails in the 'Local Folders' are still visible and accessible. They are also now only stored on your computer, so it's easy to backup. Maybe you only need to upload recent mail, but not all. Basically keeping emails in 'Local Folders' like an Archive. But if you pt emails back onto server - I would advise you only 'Copy to' imap folder, so keeping the 'Local Folders' account as an independent copy of all your emails. Again if something goes wrong then you can retry. If you choose to no upload everything, it means your new gmail account will only have all new incoming mail. Anything in an imap account cannot be truelly regarded as independent copy of server. After all an imap account can only show what is on server and all imap folders synchronise with server.

Hope this info helps.
creator: Toad-Hall

creator: dawson.thirteen

content:
There are two https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/duplication-remover/ and https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/removedupes/ which is far more popular. I can't vouch for either one.

If speed or responsive is an issue while the messages are being copied, you can turn off global search indexing and then turn it back on when copies are done.

The image you uploaded shows that you are using Account Hub. However, there are some issues with Account Hub. I suggest you disable Account Hub and then try adding a new email account again.

The following steps should disable Account Hub: "Seetings" > "General" > "Account hub" section > Untick "Create accounts in the new Account Hub".

Please see the attached image.

content:
Per poter inquadrare il problema prova a fornire queste informazioni:

  1. Versione di Thunderbird
  2. Versione del sistema operativo
  3. Provider delle caselle email (Gmail, Libero, Hotmail, etc.)
  4. Tipologia di account (POP3, IMAP)
  5. Estensioni installate
  6. Messaggi di errore che vengono visualizzati durante l'utilizzo di Thunderbird
  7. Software di sicurezza eventualmente presenti (Antivirus e simili)
  8. Screenshot del problema (se utile a chiarire il contesto)
creator: @next

content:
My Tags window & folder [View, Folders, Tags] As seen in Folder Pane. Usually 'Tags' will update the view when you click on the listed tag. So if you clicked on 'Important' - it should perform a check on everything that has been set with the 'Important' tag and refresh the display.

For example when I view mine - it's not correct until I actually select the tag name.

It's also worth checking whether you have a filter operating on the list. Check the 'Quick Filter' to see if something like 'Unread' has been enabled, because if a filter is enabled then it can even look like the list has nothing in it.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
It's likely it's not crashing but is hanging. I believe you may be experiencing a bug.

Please do the following : In Thunderbird

  • Settings > General
  • scroll down to bottom
  • click the 'Config editor' button
  • It opens in a new tab
  • In search type: force
  • look for: accessibility.force_disabled
  • default has zero 0 setting
  • click on the pencil icon
  • Remove the zero and type : 1
  • click on the tick icon to save.

Please note it will disable accessibility features such as screen readers.

Then Restart Thunderbird

A bug report has been created; link below if you want to folow it.

  • https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=1972457

If this works for you please select this comment as a 'Chosen solution' so others can also locate a solution. Thanks.
creator: Toad-Hall

content:
If the Account is IMAP Export them from Thunderbird as MBOX files using this addon https://addons.thunderbird.net/en-US/thunderbird/addon/importexporttools-ng/?src=ss

You can then import them back into Thunderbird using the same tool to the "Local Folders" account and from then on it will be up to you to make appropriate backups.

If the account is POP you already have local copies that are not connected to the server. but that does not preclude the Export process as that will then allow you to remove the original account from Thunderbird.

content:
Let me get this. You have trouble adding your account from some unnamed provider to Thunderbird so you are posting here to say goodbye. As you will. Goodbye

I would be seeking support for why it is failing before you move on to another application that will probably have exactly the same issue as it is unlikely to be a Thunderbird issue in the end.

Thunderbird is actively maintained and as far as I am aware can access ALL standards compliant mail server s(and some that are not), but that would require details of what mail provider and what error messages you get along with your use of antivirus products and VPN's

BTW most account setup problems are directly caused by antivirus products that folk purchase and install Another raft are caused by VPNs and the disabling of cookies in Thunderbird for "security" reasons. You notice I do not mention Thunderbird being the problem? That is because I have not seen an instance where Thunderbird could not connect to an IMAP, POP or SMTP server with the correct settings if it is allowed to. Not for many years anyway. It has happened, but not that I can remember a specific instance.

Most recently I generally I find folk trying to make two factor authentication work when they need to use oAUth authentication instead or ATT customers that do not understand the mail system their provider offers and is apparently unable to adequately describe via either their documentation or support staff.
creator: MattAuSupport
